citeinfo.title: USGS Data Release: Land change and carbon balance scenario projections for the State of California - model output

Sleeter, BM, DC Marvin, DR Cameron, PC Selmants, L Westerling, J Kreitler, CJ Daniel, TS Wilson, 2019, Effects of 21st century climate, land use, and disturbances on ecosystem carbon balance in California. Global Change Biology

descript.abstract: This data series provides tabular output from a series of modeling simulations for the State of California. The methods and results of this research are described in detail in Sleeter et al. (2019). We used the LUCAS model to project changes in ecosystem carbon balance resulting from land use and land use change, climate change, and ecosystem disturbances such as wildfire and drought. The model was run at a 1-km spatial resolution on an annual timestep. We simulated 32 unique scenarios, consisting of 4 land-use scenarios and 2 radiative forcing scenarios as simulated by 4 global climate models. For each scenario, we ran 100 Monte Carlo realizations of the model. Additional details describing the modeling effort can be found in the *Global Change Biology* paper. Results presented here have been aggregated from the individual cell level to either ecoregion or state-wide summaries.
descript.purpose: Terrestrial ecosystems are an important sink for atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2), sequestering ~30% of annual anthropogenic emissions and slowing the rise of atmospheric CO2. However, the future direction and magnitude of the land sink is highly uncertain. We examined how historical and projected changes in climate, land use, and ecosystem disturbances affect the carbon balance of terrestrial ecosystems in California over the period 2001-2100. We modeled 32 unique scenarios, spanning four land-use and two radiative forcing scenarios as simulated by four global climate models.

idinfo.datacred: Funding for this research was provided by the U.S. Geological Surveyâ€™s Biological Carbon Sequestration Program and Climate and Land Use Research & Development Program. Additional funding was provided by The Nature Conservancy (Grant #18WSZL00TNC201802). This work used the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE), which is supported by National Science Foundation grant number ACI-1548562.

citeinfo.title: Effects of 21st century climate, land use, and disturbances on ecosystem carbon balance in California

attracc.attraccr: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted
dataqual.complete: Data set is considered complete for the information presented, as described in the abstract. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.

horizpa.horizpar: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

vertacc.vertaccr: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

procstep.procdesc: This data series provides tabular output from a series of modeling simulations for the State of California. The methods and results of this research are described in detail in Sleeter et al. (2019). We used the LUCAS model to project changes in ecosystem carbon balance resulting from land use and land use change, climate change, and ecosystem disturbances such as wildfire and drought. The model was run at a 1-km spatial resolution on an annual timestep. We simulated 32 unique scenarios, consisting of 4 land-use scenarios and 2 radiative forcing scenarios as simulated by 4 global climate models. For each scenario, we ran 100 Monte Carlo realizations of the model. Additional details describing the modeling effort can be found in the *Global Change Biology* paper. Results presented here have been aggregated from the individual cell level to either ecoregion or state-wide summaries.

enttyp.enttypd: Carbon Stocks. The amount of carbon stored in a range of ecosystem and non-ecosystem pools, including living and dead vegetation, soils, harvested products, and aquatic and atmosphere pools. Measured in Tg C.

attr.attrdef: Denotes whether a record's Carbon Flow was associated with a particular transition in land use or land cover. Carbon Flows that occur normally during non-transition periods have a value of 'TransitionGroup'='NA'. See stsm-transitions-state.zip for descriptions of each Transition Group.

attr.attrdef: Denotes either 1) the sum total of carbon transfer as a result of a LULC transition or ecosystem process, or 2) the net balance of carbon transferred to and from the atmosphere.

edom.edomvd: Total amount of carbon emitted to the atmosphere due to agricultural expansion
Total amount of carbon emitted to the atmosphere from live biomass
Total amount of carbon emitted to the atmosphere due to forest clearcut harvesting
Total amount of carbon emitted to the atmosphere due to wildland fire
Total amount of carbon emitted to the atmosphere due to orchard removal
Total amount of carbon emitted to the atmosphere due to urbanization
Total amount of tree biomass carbon transferrred to the Wood Products pool due to agricultural expansion
Total amount of tree biomass carbon transferrred to the Wood Products pool due to forest clearcut harvesting
Total amount of crop biomass carbon transferrred to the Agricultural Products pool in the form of grain
Total amount of crop biomass carbon transferrred to the Agricultural Products pool in the form of straw
Total amount of tree biomass carbon transferrred to the Wood Products pool due to forest thinning
Total amount of tree biomass carbon transferrred to the Wood Products pool due to urbanization
Total amount of carbon transferred from soil to water due to leaching
Total amount of carbon transferred to the atmosphere due to changes in land use and land cover
Total amount of tree live biomass carbon transferred to standing dead due to tree death
Total amount of tree live biomass carbon transferred to standing dead due to tree mortality from fire
Total amount of tree live biomass carbon transferred to standing dead due to tree mortality from harvesting
Total amount of tree live biomass carbon transferred to standing dead due to tree mortality from drought induced insect activity
Net Ecosystem Carbon Balance, the net balance of carbon transferred from the Atmosphere by Growth (NPP) and all Emissions to the Atmosphere, including Fire, Harvest, etc.
Net Ecosystem Production, the net balance of carbon transferred from the Atmosphere by Growth and to the Atmosphere by non-disturbance emission (Rh)
Net Primary Production, the total amount of carbon carbon removed from the atmosphere due to plant growth
Heterotrophic respiration, total amount of carbon transferred to the atmosphere during the decomposition of dead organic matter

attr.attrdef: Refers to the Transition Group or Transition Type within a Group. Transition Groups describe the transition in broad terms (e.g. FIRE, URBANIZATION). Transition Types specify the land cover classes involved in the transition, the intensity of the transition (e.g., High, Medium, Low), or the specific type of transition.

attrdomv.udom: Refers to the Transition Group or Transition Type within a Group. Transition Groups describe the transition in broad terms (e.g. FIRE, URBANIZATION). Transition Types specify the land cover classes involved in the transition, the intensity of the transition (e.g., High, Medium, Low), or the specific type of transition.

attr.attrdef: Specifies whether the record refers to a Transition Group or a Transition Type within a Group

attrdomv.udom: Specifies whether the record refers to a Transition Group or a Transition Type within a Group.

overview.eaover:
Tabular results are provided describing the following five types of output from the model.
1. Carbon Stocks - The amount of carbon stored in a range of ecosystem and non-ecosystem pools, including living and dead vegetation, soils, harvested products, and aquatic and atmosphere pools. ( Tg C) 2. Carbon Flows - The annual rate of transfer of carbon from one carbon stock to another. (Tg C yr^-1^ ) 3. Carbon Net Fluxes - The annual net flux of carbon, expressed as Net Primary Productivity (NPP), Heterotrophic Respiration (Rh), Net Ecosystem Productivity (NEP), Net Ecosystem Carbon Balance (NECB), and fluxes due to land use, land-use change, and disturbances (LULCC). (Tg C yr^-1^) 4. LULC Area - The annual amount of land classified into a set of discrete LULC classes (e.g. forests, developed, grasslands, etc...). (km^2^ ) 5. LULC Transition Area - The annual amount of land projected to change from one LULC class type to another. (km^2^ yr^-1^ )
Each of the five datasets are provided as State-level and Ecoregion-level summaries. Furthermore, output data area available for each Monte Carlo iteration or as means with a 95% confidence interval. Tabular output data use the following naming convention:
**domain**_**output**_by_scenario_timestep_**values**.csv
where, **domain** defines whether results are summarized by *ecoregion* or by *state*, **output** defines the *type* of data in the file, and **values** defines whether the output data are presented for each Monte Carlo realization (i.e. *iteration*) or as means with 95% confidence intervals (i.e. *95ci*). Users wishing to create new summaries by aggregating the data in new ways, should use the tables with each Monte Carlo iteration available.
Units: 1. Amount: The projected quantity for each Monte Carlo realization of the model + Carbon: Teragrams (Tg) + Land Use/Land Cover: Square Kilometers (km2) 2. Mean: The average as calculated for each record over the 100 Monte Carlo realizations of the model. 3. Lower: The lower range of values (2.5%) calculated for the 95% Monte Carlo confidence interval. 4. Upper: The upper range of values (97.5%) calculated for the 95% Monte Carlo confidence interval.
overview.eadetcit:
Tabular results are provided describing the following five types of output from the model.
1. Carbon Stocks - The amount of carbon stored in a range of ecosystem and non-ecosystem pools, including living and dead vegetation, soils, harvested products, and aquatic and atmosphere pools. ( Tg C) 2. Carbon Flows - The annual rate of transfer of carbon from one carbon stock to another. (Tg C yr^-1^ ) 3. Carbon Net Fluxes - The annual net flux of carbon, expressed as Net Primary Productivity (NPP), Heterotrophic Respiration (Rh), Net Ecosystem Productivity (NEP), Net Ecosystem Carbon Balance (NECB), and fluxes due to land use, land-use change, and disturbances (LULCC). (Tg C yr^-1^) 4. LULC Area - The annual amount of land classified into a set of discrete LULC classes (e.g. forests, developed, grasslands, etc...). (km^2^ ) 5. LULC Transition Area - The annual amount of land projected to change from one LULC class type to another. (km^2^ yr^-1^ )
Each of the five datasets are provided as State-level and Ecoregion-level summaries. Furthermore, output data area available for each Monte Carlo iteration or as means with a 95% confidence interval. Tabular output data use the following naming convention:
**domain**_**output**_by_scenario_timestep_**values**.csv
where, **domain** defines whether results are summarized by *ecoregion* or by *state*, **output** defines the *type* of data in the file, and **values** defines whether the output data are presented for each Monte Carlo realization (i.e. *iteration*) or as means with 95% confidence intervals (i.e. *95ci*). Users wishing to create new summaries by aggregating the data in new ways, should use the tables with each Monte Carlo iteration available.
Units: 1. Amount: The projected quantity for each Monte Carlo realization of the model + Carbon: Teragrams (Tg) + Land Use/Land Cover: Square Kilometers (km2) 2. Mean: The average as calculated for each record over the 100 Monte Carlo realizations of the model. 3. Lower: The lower range of values (2.5%) calculated for the 95% Monte Carlo confidence interval. 4. Upper: The upper range of values (97.5%) calculated for the 95% Monte Carlo confidence interval.

cntaddr.address: Denver Federal Center, Building 810, Mail Stop 302

distinfo.distliab: The authors of these data request that data users contact them regarding intended use and to assist with understanding limitations and interpretation. Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data for other purposes, nor on all computer systems, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.
